item.title: Indexicals
item.description: A grammatical construct in natural languages which is explicitly context-sensitive. Examples: pronouns, such as “I” and “he” “here” “today” These are an important case for any general semantic theory to address.

item.title: Neurath's boat
item.description: We are like sailors who on the open sea must reconstruct their ship but are never able to start afresh from the bottom.

item.title: Ontology
item.description: The theory of what really is, or the what is there ‘objectively’.

item.title: Possible worlds semantics
item.description: Possible worlds semantics is a semantics for Modal logic. John Etchemendy warns us to not confuse possible models in Tarski model theory with possible worlds in his The Concept of Logical Consequence.

item.title: Reference
item.description: Grammar Grammatically, one signals reference with of. E.g.: I’m thinking of a number As a relation Reference has been thought of as a relation between linguistic terms and things in the world.

item.title: Representation
item.description: Representation is a theory of the relation between appearance and reality. A successor concept to theories of resemblance Premodern theories understood relation between appearance and reality in terms of resemblance (sharing properties).

item.title: The Frege-Geach problem
item.description: A problem for people who subscribe to emotivism. Sets a critirion of adequacy for them. Also sometimes called the embedding problem.

item.title: Truth
item.description: Two broad conceptions Truth as “correspondence with reality” Truth as “what is best in the way of belief” The former is a modern, representationalist rendering of Aristotle’s “saying of what is, that it is, and of what is not, that it is not”.
